section1.p1: You should complete this form to support your patient's finances and to encourage your patient to see which benefits they may be entitled to. This can be done as part of a discussion about future care planning or if requested by your patient or their representative.
section1.p2: It is understood that determining life expectancy in these circumstances is not an exact science and so you will not face any negative consequences from the factual information you supply, for example if your patient lives longer than 6 months.
section1.p3: For Disability Living Allowance, Attendance Allowance and Personal Independence Payment only, any person representing the patient can make a 3rd party claim on their behalf, even if the patient is unaware that a claim is being made. In this circumstance the form should be issued on request to the representative.
section1.h3: Patients who may not know the true nature of their illness
section1.p4: When a patient asks you for a DS1500 form, please do not assume that they understand the special rules criteria or that these apply in certain circumstances to people with progressive, life-limiting disease.

section2.p: This form can be completed by a registered clinician such as a:
section2.inset-text: A registered nurse needs to have acquired the expert knowledge and clinical competencies to undertake the assessment. They may be working in a role such as an advanced nurse practitioner, a Macmillan nurse, a clinical specialist nurse or a practice nurse with expertise in long term conditions management.

section3.p: This form allows you to provide further evidence to enable us to make a decision on your patient's claim. It is not a claim form, as you cannot claim on behalf of your patients. It will not normally be necessary for you to examine the patient. You may use your own knowledge and the patient's records to get the information you need.

section4.p1: The digital DS1500 service allows you to access and complete this form online. This means the form arrives instantly, which reduces waiting time for your patient.
section4.p2: Alternatively, for Personal Independence Payment (England and Scotland) only, you can complete form DS1500 and the fee form electronically and submit it to us by using the NHSmail system. No signature is required. We can provide you with an electronic PDF version of the DS1500 and DS1500 fee form.
section4.p3: We need you to provide the following information by email from your current NHS.net email address:

ul.li1: your NHS.net email address or addresses
ul.li2: your surgery/hospital/office postal address and telephone number
ul.li3: a list of medical professionals using the same NHS.net email address who complete the DS1500 and/or DS1500 fee form
ul.li4: whether you need the DS1500 and DS1500 fee form, or the DS1500 only

section4.p5bold: Do not encrypt any part of the email.
section4.p5: Any email from a non-NHS.net account will be automatically deleted. If you do not have an NHS.net email address, contact your local IT helpdesk to request an account.
section4.p6: To use the clerical return service, send your completed DS1500 form and claim fee form to us (see the Claiming a fee section).
section4.p7: When returning DS1500 forms, ensure a separate envelope is used for each individual patient. Do not stable documents together.

section5.p1: You can claim a fee if you are a GP or GMC registered consultant, but only if you have authorised this form by signing it at the end.
section5.p2: To claim your fee, fill out the fee claim form which will be presented at the end of the digital DS1500 form.
section5.p3: We will pay your fee into your bank or building society account.
section5.inset-text: MacMillan nurses, Nurse Specialists and practice nurses can complete the DS1500, but only GPs and GMC registered consultants may claim a fee.

section6.p2: If your patient meets the special rules criteria, their benefit claim will be processed as a priority and in the majority of cases they will receive the highest rate of benefit.

section7.p1: As we need to deal with these claims urgently, the healthcare professional will usually contact you by telephone.
section7.p2: You may be contacted by a healthcare professional working for one of our clinical assessment providers:

ul.li1: if we need clarification of some of the information on the DS1500 to help with our decision about the claim, or
ul.li2: if the patient has made a claim under the Special Rules procedures but has not submitted a DS1500 and we need clinical information to support the claim
